title: Transforming Federal Customer Experience and Service Delivery To Rebuild Trust in Government

enrichment.summary: This executive order directs federal agencies to improve how government services are designed and delivered to the public, making them simpler, faster, more accessible, and equitable. It emphasizes using customer feedback, modern technology, and coordinated efforts across agencies to reduce bureaucratic burdens and build public trust in government.
potential_concerns: Efforts to modernize digital government services may unintentionally create accessibility barriers for individuals-with-disabilities lacking assistive technologies or digital literacy.

Streamlining application and enrollment processes may inadequately protect privacy or civil rights safeguards, particularly impacting low-income individuals and underserved racial/ethnic groups such as native-americans-indigenous-peoples and undocumented immigrants.

Consolidation of services and reliance on online platforms could disadvantage veterans and elderly Medicare and Medicaid beneficiaries who may have limited internet access or prefer in-person assistance.

Coordination across federal and state agencies to reduce paperwork burdens might face legal and bureaucratic challenges that delay relief to small-business-owners and tribal-governments relying heavily on timely federal assistance.
Efforts to reduce 'time taxes' risk oversimplifying complex eligibility criteria, potentially excluding or confusing marginalized groups and undermining equitable access.
